definitions.anatomy_trains: Refers to the myofascial meridians described by Thomas Myers that interconnect muscles and fascia throughout the body. They explain how tension or movement in one area can influence distant regions.
anatomy_trains_list: Superficial Front Line - Connects the anterior muscles and fascia from the feet to the head.
Superficial Back Line - Runs along the posterior side of the body, linking the calves, hamstrings, back, and neck.
Deep Front Line - Involves the deep core muscles and fascia that support the spine and internal organs.
Lateral Line - Supports side-to-side stability by connecting the lateral muscles of the trunk and limbs.
Spiral Line - Integrates diagonal and rotational forces across the body through interconnected fascial fibers.
Arm Lines - Encompasses the myofascial connections in the upper limbs, supporting shoulder and arm movements.

muscles.primary: The main muscles that directly produce the movement. These are the primary force generators.
muscles.secondary: The muscles that assist, stabilize, or support the movement, helping to maintain form and efficiency.

definitions.nasm_category: A classification based on NASM guidelines that identifies the primary movement action of the exercise (e.g., push, pull, stabilization).
definitions.movement_type: Describes whether the movement is dynamic (continuous), compound (multiple joints), isometric (static hold), or plyometric (explosive).
definitions.equipment_type: Specifies the tool used in the exercise (e.g., Bodyweight, Barbell, Dumbbell, Kettlebell, Resistance Band, Cable, Machine, etc.).
definitions.movement_plane: The anatomical plane in which the movement occurs (e.g., Sagittal, Frontal, Transverse).
definitions.unilateral_bilateral: Indicates if the exercise is unilateral (one limb at a time) or bilateral (both limbs simultaneously).
definitions.stability_requirement: Describes the level of stabilization needed (e.g., stable surface, dynamic stabilization).
definitions.intensity_modality: Specifies how the load is applied (e.g., dynamic, controlled, explosive, isometric, plyometric).
definitions.fascia: Details on fascial engagement and benefits during the exercise.
definitions.tendons: Key tendons loaded during the exercise and associated considerations.
definitions.ligaments: Primary ligaments involved and any precautions.
definitions.joints: Joints involved with their actions and range-of-motion requirements.
definitions.progressions_regressions: Guidelines for modifying the exercise for various ability levels.
definitions.tempo_timing: Recommended pacing for the exercise phases.
definitions.safety_contraindications: Precautions and contraindications for safe execution.
definitions.coach_tips: Additional cues and tips for optimal performance.
definitions.training_context: How the exercise fits into broader training programs.

Bodyweight Squat (Air Squat) [oai_citati.instructions: Perform a squat with proper depth and form.
Bodyweight Squat (Air Squat) [oai_citati.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: use support.
Bodyweight Squat (Air Squat) [oai_citati.tempo_timing: 2-3 sec down, brief pause, 1-2 sec up.
Bodyweight Squat (Air Squat) [oai_citati.safety_contraindications: Avoid if knee pain is present.
Bodyweight Squat (Air Squat) [oai_citati.coach_tips: Keep your chest up and knees tracking.
Bodyweight Squat (Air Squat) [oai_citati.training_context: Suitable for general strength and mobility.

Wall Squat (Wall Sit) [oai_citation_attr.instructions: Lean against a wall and hold a squat position.
Wall Squat (Wall Sit) [oai_citation_attr.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: shorten hold.

Box Squat (to Bench/Box) [oai_citation_a.instructions: Sit back onto a box then stand up explosively.
Box Squat (to Bench/Box) [oai_citation_a.progressions_regressions: Progress: add load; regress: use a higher box.
Box Squat (to Bench/Box) [oai_citation_a.safety_contraindications: Avoid if lower back pain is present.
Box Squat (to Bench/Box) [oai_citation_a.coach_tips: Focus on sitting back rather than dropping.

Prisoner Squat [oai_citation_attribution.instructions: Perform a squat with hands behind the head to encourage upright posture.
Prisoner Squat [oai_citation_attribution.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: shallow squat.
Prisoner Squat [oai_citation_attribution.coach_tips: Keep your chest up and avoid rounding.
Prisoner Squat [oai_citation_attribution.training_context: Useful for core engagement and posture training.

Sumo Squat (Plie Squat) [oai_citation_at.tendons: Moderate tendon loading in inner thighs.
Sumo Squat (Plie Squat) [oai_citation_at.instructions: Perform a squat with a wide stance and toes pointed slightly outward.
Sumo Squat (Plie Squat) [oai_citation_at.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: reduce depth.
Sumo Squat (Plie Squat) [oai_citation_at.safety_contraindications: Avoid if inner knee pain is present.
Sumo Squat (Plie Squat) [oai_citation_at.training_context: Great for adductor strength and hip mobility.

Close-Stance Squat [oai_citation_attribu.instructions: Perform a squat with feet closer together than shoulder-width.
Close-Stance Squat [oai_citation_attribu.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: reduce depth.

Front Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attr.fascia: Activates front fascial chains and core fascia.
Front Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attr.instructions: Hold the bar in front of your shoulders with elbows high; squat down keeping torso upright.
Front Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attr.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: use lighter load or partial ROM.
Front Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attr.tempo_timing: 2-3 sec eccentric, brief pause, 1-2 sec concentric.
Front Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attr.coach_tips: Keep elbows high to maintain bar position.
Front Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attr.training_context: Emphasizes quad and core strength, often used in Olympic weightlifting prep.

Back Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attri.fascia: Engages both anterior and posterior fascial lines.
Back Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attri.tendons: High load on patellar and Achilles tendons.
Back Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attri.ligaments: Knee ligaments (ACL, PCL, MCL, LCL) are engaged.
Back Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attri.instructions: Perform a squat with a barbell on your back; lower until thighs are parallel, then drive upward through your heels.
Back Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attri.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase load or add pause at bottom; regress: reduce depth or use a safety box.
Back Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attri.tempo_timing: 2-3 sec down, brief pause, 1-2 sec up.
Back Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attri.safety_contraindications: Avoid if experiencing knee or lower back pain.
Back Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attri.coach_tips: Keep a neutral spine and ensure knees track over toes.
Back Squat (Barbell) [oai_citation_attri.training_context: A foundational lift for building lower-body strength and power.

Overhead Squat [oai_citation_attribution.fascia: Stretches and engages deep core and posterior fascial lines.
Overhead Squat [oai_citation_attribution.tendons: Loads patellar and Achilles tendons moderately.
Overhead Squat [oai_citation_attribution.ligaments: Engages multiple joint ligaments for stability.
Overhead Squat [oai_citation_attribution.instructions: Perform a squat with the bar overhead (or arms fully extended) while maintaining proper alignment.
Overhead Squat [oai_citation_attribution.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase load or depth; regress: practice with lighter weight or on a box.
Overhead Squat [oai_citation_attribution.tempo_timing: Controlled descent and ascent with brief pause if needed.
Overhead Squat [oai_citation_attribution.safety_contraindications: Avoid if shoulder or ankle mobility is limited.
Overhead Squat [oai_citation_attribution.coach_tips: Focus on keeping the bar path vertical and core tight.
Overhead Squat [oai_citation_attribution.training_context: Used to assess mobility and strength; common in Olympic weightlifting training.

Zercher Squat [oai_citation_attribution:.fascia: Activates deep core fascia and upper back fascia.
Zercher Squat [oai_citation_attribution:.ligaments: Knee and hip ligaments are engaged.
Zercher Squat [oai_citation_attribution:.instructions: Hold the bar in the crook of your elbows and perform a squat, keeping torso upright.
Zercher Squat [oai_citation_attribution:.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase weight; regress: use lighter weight or shorter ROM.
Zercher Squat [oai_citation_attribution:.safety_contraindications: Avoid if lower back or elbow issues exist.
Zercher Squat [oai_citation_attribution:.coach_tips: Keep elbows high and maintain a straight back.
Zercher Squat [oai_citation_attribution:.training_context: Targets core and quadriceps with a unique load distribution.

Goblet Squat (Dumbbell or Kettlebell) [o.fascia: Activates core and lower body fascia.
Goblet Squat (Dumbbell or Kettlebell) [o.instructions: Hold the weight at chest level; squat down keeping chest up and core engaged.
Goblet Squat (Dumbbell or Kettlebell) [o.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight or depth; regress: perform without weight.
Goblet Squat (Dumbbell or Kettlebell) [o.safety_contraindications: Avoid if knee pain is present.
Goblet Squat (Dumbbell or Kettlebell) [o.training_context: A beginner-friendly squat variation for strength and hypertrophy.

muscles.primary: Pectoralis Major, Anterior Deltoid, Triceps Brachii

Barbell Bench Press [oai_citation_attrib.instructions: Lie on a bench, grip the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width, lower it to mid-chest, and press upward.
Barbell Bench Press [oai_citation_attrib.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight or use pause reps; regress: use dumbbell press.
Barbell Bench Press [oai_citation_attrib.tempo_timing: 2 sec down, brief pause, 1-2 sec up.
Barbell Bench Press [oai_citation_attrib.coach_tips: Maintain scapular retraction and controlled movement.
Barbell Bench Press [oai_citation_attrib.training_context: Essential for upper body strength and hypertrophy.

muscles.primary: Pectoralis Major, Anterior Deltoid, Triceps Brachii

Dumbbell Bench Press.fascia: Similar to bench press, activates chest fascia.
Dumbbell Bench Press.instructions: Lie on a bench holding dumbbells at chest level; press upward until arms are extended.
Dumbbell Bench Press.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase weight; regress: reduce load.
Dumbbell Bench Press.safety_contraindications: Ensure proper grip and controlled motion.
Dumbbell Bench Press.coach_tips: Keep elbows at a comfortable angle.

muscles.primary: Upper Pectoralis Major, Anterior Deltoid, Triceps Brachii

Incline Bench Press.tendons: Moderate tendon load on chest and arms.
Incline Bench Press.instructions: Perform on an inclined bench, lowering the weight to the upper chest and pressing upward.
Incline Bench Press.progressions_regressions: Progress: add load; regress: lower weight or use machine.
Incline Bench Press.safety_contraindications: Avoid if shoulder pain is present.
Incline Bench Press.coach_tips: Focus on the contraction of the upper chest.
Incline Bench Press.training_context: Ideal for targeting the upper chest and shoulders.

Decline Bench Press.instructions: Lie on a decline bench; lower the weight to the lower chest and press up.
Decline Bench Press.progressions_regressions: Progress: add load; regress: use lighter weight or machine.
Decline Bench Press.safety_contraindications: Avoid if lower chest or shoulder pain exists.
Decline Bench Press.training_context: Useful for emphasizing the lower chest region.

muscles.primary: Pectoralis Major, Anterior Deltoid, Triceps Brachii

Push-Up (Standard) [oai_citation_attribu.instructions: Assume a plank position; lower your chest to the floor and push back up.
Push-Up (Standard) [oai_citation_attribu.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight or elevate feet; regress: perform on knees.
Push-Up (Standard) [oai_citation_attribu.tempo_timing: Controlled, 2 sec down and 1-2 sec up.
Push-Up (Standard) [oai_citation_attribu.safety_contraindications: Avoid if wrist or shoulder pain exists.
Push-Up (Standard) [oai_citation_attribu.coach_tips: Maintain a straight line and engage your core.
Push-Up (Standard) [oai_citation_attribu.training_context: A fundamental bodyweight exercise for overall upper-body strength.

Incline Push-Up.fascia: Basic fascia activation of the chest.
Incline Push-Up.instructions: Perform push-ups with your hands elevated on a bench.
Incline Push-Up.progressions_regressions: Progress: lower the bench gradually; regress: increase bench height.
Incline Push-Up.coach_tips: Keep a straight line and controlled descent.
Incline Push-Up.training_context: Eases into standard push-ups and reduces load on shoulders.

Decline Push-Up.fascia: Activates chest fascia with increased load.
Decline Push-Up.instructions: Perform push-ups with your feet elevated on a bench.
Decline Push-Up.progressions_regressions: Progress: lower the bench gradually; regress: use a flat surface.
Decline Push-Up.safety_contraindications: Avoid if lower chest or shoulder pain exists.
Decline Push-Up.coach_tips: Focus on controlled movement and maintaining alignment.
Decline Push-Up.training_context: Increases difficulty of standard push-ups, emphasizing the upper chest.

Diamond Push-Up (Close-Grip).instructions: Form a diamond shape with your hands under your chest and perform a push-up.
Diamond Push-Up (Close-Grip).progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: perform on knees.
Diamond Push-Up (Close-Grip).safety_contraindications: Avoid if wrist or elbow pain exists.
Diamond Push-Up (Close-Grip).coach_tips: Keep elbows close to the body.
Diamond Push-Up (Close-Grip).training_context: Great for targeting the triceps and inner chest.

Wide Push-Up.fascia: Engages chest fascia with a wider movement path.
Wide Push-Up.tendons: Moderate load on chest and shoulder tendons.
Wide Push-Up.ligaments: Shoulder joint stabilized by proper form.
Wide Push-Up.instructions: Perform push-ups with a wider hand placement.
Wide Push-Up.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: use knees.
Wide Push-Up.training_context: Emphasizes the pectorals through an increased ROM.

Clap Push-Up (Plyometric Push-Up).fascia: Activates dynamic fascia response in the upper body.
Clap Push-Up (Plyometric Push-Up).tendons: High load on arm tendons due to explosive movement.
Clap Push-Up (Plyometric Push-Up).instructions: Perform a push-up explosively so your hands leave the floor to clap, then catch and descend under control.
Clap Push-Up (Plyometric Push-Up).progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight vest; regress: perform on knees.
Clap Push-Up (Plyometric Push-Up).safety_contraindications: Avoid if joint pain is present.
Clap Push-Up (Plyometric Push-Up).coach_tips: Ensure a soft landing and controlled movement.
Clap Push-Up (Plyometric Push-Up).training_context: Used to build upper-body explosive strength.

Parallel Bar Dip [oai_citation_attributi.instructions: Support yourself on parallel bars; lower your body by bending your elbows, then push back up.
Parallel Bar Dip [oai_citation_attributi.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: use bench dips.
Parallel Bar Dip [oai_citation_attributi.safety_contraindications: Avoid if shoulder or elbow pain exists.
Parallel Bar Dip [oai_citation_attributi.coach_tips: Keep elbows close and avoid swinging.
Parallel Bar Dip [oai_citation_attributi.training_context: A key compound movement for upper body strength.

Ring Dip.fascia: Engages upper body fascia with stabilization demands.
Ring Dip.tendons: Loads arm tendons; caution is needed.
Ring Dip.instructions: Perform dips using rings; lower and press while maintaining strict form.
Ring Dip.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: use assisted rings or parallel bars.
Ring Dip.safety_contraindications: Avoid if unable to stabilize on rings.
Ring Dip.coach_tips: Focus on core stability and smooth transitions.
Ring Dip.training_context: Used to challenge stability and strength simultaneously.

Bench Dip.instructions: Place your hands on a bench behind you and dip your body downward, then press back up.
Bench Dip.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: keep feet on the ground.
Bench Dip.safety_contraindications: Avoid if shoulder pain is present.
Bench Dip.coach_tips: Keep your back close to the bench.
Bench Dip.training_context: An accessible dip variation for beginners.

Assisted Dip (Machine or Band).fascia: Minimal active fascia due to assistance.
Assisted Dip (Machine or Band).instructions: Perform dips with assistance to complete the movement with proper form.
Assisted Dip (Machine or Band).progressions_regressions: Progress: reduce assistance; regress: increase support.
Assisted Dip (Machine or Band).training_context: Ideal for those building dip strength.

Straight Bar Dip (Front Bar).instructions: Perform dips using a straight bar held at arm's length; lower and push up with controlled form.
Straight Bar Dip (Front Bar).progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: use parallel bars.
Straight Bar Dip (Front Bar).coach_tips: Maintain a steady pace and proper alignment.
Straight Bar Dip (Front Bar).training_context: Provides a different grip and stress pattern compared to parallel bar dips.

Weighted Dip.fascia: Activates upper body fascia under load.
Weighted Dip.instructions: Perform dips with additional weight attached via a belt; lower and press up with controlled form.
Weighted Dip.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase added weight; regress: reduce weight.
Weighted Dip.safety_contraindications: Avoid if joint pain is present.
Weighted Dip.training_context: Advanced variation for increased strength and hypertrophy.

Pull-Up (Wide Grip) [oai_citation_attrib.fascia: Engages the back fascia and core fascia.
Pull-Up (Wide Grip) [oai_citation_attrib.tendons: Loads biceps and forearm tendons moderately.
Pull-Up (Wide Grip) [oai_citation_attrib.instructions: Grip the bar with a wide overhand grip; pull your chin over the bar with a controlled motion.
Pull-Up (Wide Grip) [oai_citation_attrib.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight or increase reps; regress: use assistance or perform negatives.
Pull-Up (Wide Grip) [oai_citation_attrib.tempo_timing: 1-2 sec up, brief pause, 2-3 sec down.
Pull-Up (Wide Grip) [oai_citation_attrib.safety_contraindications: Avoid if shoulder pain is present.
Pull-Up (Wide Grip) [oai_citation_attrib.coach_tips: Engage your core and retract your scapulae throughout.
Pull-Up (Wide Grip) [oai_citation_attrib.training_context: A staple for developing back and arm strength.

Chin-Up (Underhand Grip).fascia: Engages back and arm fascia effectively.
Chin-Up (Underhand Grip).instructions: Use a supinated (underhand) grip; pull your chin over the bar with controlled movement.
Chin-Up (Underhand Grip).progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: use resistance bands.
Chin-Up (Underhand Grip).coach_tips: Focus on pulling with your back rather than just your arms.
Chin-Up (Underhand Grip).training_context: Often used to build bicep and lat strength.

Neutral Grip Pull-Up.tendons: Moderate load on biceps and forearm tendons.
Neutral Grip Pull-Up.instructions: Perform a pull-up using a neutral grip; pull with a controlled, vertical motion.
Neutral Grip Pull-Up.progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight; regress: use assistance.
Neutral Grip Pull-Up.coach_tips: Keep your body stable and avoid swinging.

Lat Pulldown (Cable).ligaments: Minimal stress due to guided motion.
Lat Pulldown (Cable).instructions: Sit at the machine and pull the bar down toward your chest.
Lat Pulldown (Cable).progressions_regressions: Progress: increase weight; regress: use less resistance.
Lat Pulldown (Cable).coach_tips: Maintain proper posture and controlled descent.
Lat Pulldown (Cable).training_context: Popular for isolating and strengthening the lats.

Bent-Over Barbell Row.tendons: Moderate load on biceps and forearm tendons.
Bent-Over Barbell Row.instructions: Hinge at the hips, pull the barbell to your torso, and return to the starting position.
Bent-Over Barbell Row.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase weight; regress: use dumbbells or chest-supported row.
Bent-Over Barbell Row.safety_contraindications: Avoid if lower back pain is present.
Bent-Over Barbell Row.coach_tips: Maintain a flat back and proper hip hinge.
Bent-Over Barbell Row.training_context: A staple for developing back thickness and strength.

One-Arm Dumbbell Row.instructions: Place one knee on a bench; row the dumbbell to your hip.
One-Arm Dumbbell Row.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase weight; regress: use lighter dumbbell or assisted row.
One-Arm Dumbbell Row.safety_contraindications: Avoid if lower back or shoulder issues are present.
One-Arm Dumbbell Row.coach_tips: Focus on a full range of motion and a strong scapular squeeze.
One-Arm Dumbbell Row.training_context: Ideal for unilateral back strength and correcting imbalances.

T-Bar Row.instructions: Row the T-bar toward your chest using a V-handle.
T-Bar Row.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase weight; regress: use a lighter load.
T-Bar Row.safety_contraindications: Avoid if experiencing lower back strain.
T-Bar Row.coach_tips: Maintain proper posture and a full contraction at the top.
T-Bar Row.training_context: Effective for building back thickness and power.

Seated Cable Row.fascia: Engages back fascia with constant tension.
Seated Cable Row.ligaments: Minimal stress due to machine guidance.
Seated Cable Row.instructions: Sit and pull the cable handle toward your torso.
Seated Cable Row.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase resistance; regress: reduce weight.
Seated Cable Row.coach_tips: Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together.
Seated Cable Row.training_context: Widely used to target the mid-back muscles.

Inverted Row (Bodyweight Row).instructions: Lie underneath a bar and pull your chest up to the bar.
Inverted Row (Bodyweight Row).progressions_regressions: Progress: elevate feet or add weight; regress: use a higher bar or TRX version.
Inverted Row (Bodyweight Row).safety_contraindications: Avoid if core strength is lacking.
Inverted Row (Bodyweight Row).coach_tips: Keep your body in a straight line.
Inverted Row (Bodyweight Row).training_context: Great for developing pulling strength and core stability.

Overhead Press (Military Press) [oai_cit.fascia: Activates shoulder and upper body fascia.
Overhead Press (Military Press) [oai_cit.instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and press the barbell overhead with controlled motion while maintaining core stability.
Overhead Press (Military Press) [oai_cit.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase load; regress: use dumbbells or a seated variation.
Overhead Press (Military Press) [oai_cit.tempo_timing: 2-3 sec down, brief pause, 1-2 sec up.
Overhead Press (Military Press) [oai_cit.coach_tips: Keep a tight core and vertical bar path.
Overhead Press (Military Press) [oai_cit.training_context: Fundamental for building shoulder strength and stability.

Dumbbell Shoulder Press.tendons: Loads deltoid and triceps tendons moderately.
Dumbbell Shoulder Press.instructions: Press dumbbells overhead from shoulder level with a controlled motion.
Dumbbell Shoulder Press.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase weight; regress: use a seated variation.
Dumbbell Shoulder Press.coach_tips: Focus on even movement and core engagement.

Arnold Press (Rotational Shoulder Press).tendons: Moderate load on rotator cuff tendons.
Arnold Press (Rotational Shoulder Press).instructions: Start with dumbbells at shoulder height with palms facing you; as you press up, rotate your palms forward.
Arnold Press (Rotational Shoulder Press).progressions_regressions: Progress: increase load; regress: use lighter weights.
Arnold Press (Rotational Shoulder Press).tempo_timing: Smooth controlled rotation with the press.
Arnold Press (Rotational Shoulder Press).safety_contraindications: Avoid if shoulder mobility is limited.
Arnold Press (Rotational Shoulder Press).coach_tips: Ensure full range of motion with controlled rotation.

Machine Shoulder Press [oai_citation_att.fascia: Limited active fascia due to machine support.
Machine Shoulder Press [oai_citation_att.ligaments: Provides joint stability via fixed path.
Machine Shoulder Press [oai_citation_att.instructions: Sit on the machine and press upward following the fixed path.
Machine Shoulder Press [oai_citation_att.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase resistance; regress: reduce weight.
Machine Shoulder Press [oai_citation_att.safety_contraindications: Avoid if shoulder issues are present.
Machine Shoulder Press [oai_citation_att.coach_tips: Focus on a smooth, full range of motion.
Machine Shoulder Press [oai_citation_att.training_context: Ideal for isolating the shoulder press with guided stability.

Behind-the-Neck Press [oai_citation_attr.fascia: Activates shoulder fascia in a unique manner due to the position.
Behind-the-Neck Press [oai_citation_attr.instructions: Perform the press with the bar behind your neck; lower and press upward with strict control.
Behind-the-Neck Press [oai_citation_attr.progressions_regressions: Progress: only if shoulder mobility is excellent; regress: use a standard overhead press.
Behind-the-Neck Press [oai_citation_attr.safety_contraindications: Not recommended for those with shoulder issues.
Behind-the-Neck Press [oai_citation_attr.coach_tips: Use very light weight and proper technique.
Behind-the-Neck Press [oai_citation_attr.training_context: An advanced variation with higher injury risk.

Lateral Raise (Dumbbell Side Raise).instructions: Raise dumbbells out to the side until shoulder height; lower slowly.
Lateral Raise (Dumbbell Side Raise).progressions_regressions: Progress: add weight slightly; regress: use lighter dumbbells.
Lateral Raise (Dumbbell Side Raise).coach_tips: Maintain a slight bend in your elbows.
Lateral Raise (Dumbbell Side Raise).training_context: Commonly used for isolating lateral delts.

Front Raise (Dumbbell).instructions: Raise dumbbells in front until shoulder height; lower slowly.
Front Raise (Dumbbell).progressions_regressions: Progress: increase weight; regress: use lighter dumbbells.
Front Raise (Dumbbell).coach_tips: Maintain strict form and avoid momentum.
Front Raise (Dumbbell).training_context: Used to isolate the front deltoids.

Rear Delt Fly (Reverse Fly).instructions: With a slight bend in your elbows, raise weights out to the sides until shoulder level; lower slowly.
Rear Delt Fly (Reverse Fly).progressions_regressions: Progress: increase weight; regress: use lighter weight.
Rear Delt Fly (Reverse Fly).coach_tips: Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades at the top.
Rear Delt Fly (Reverse Fly).training_context: Effective for targeting the rear deltoids and mid-back.

Cable Lateral Raise.fascia: Activates shoulder fascia with constant tension.
Cable Lateral Raise.instructions: Stand and raise the cable handle to shoulder height; lower slowly.
Cable Lateral Raise.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase resistance; regress: use lighter load.
Cable Lateral Raise.coach_tips: Keep movement strict and avoid momentum.

Face Pull (for Rear Delts/Scapular).instructions: Pull the cable or band toward your face while squeezing your shoulder blades together.
Face Pull (for Rear Delts/Scapular).progressions_regressions: Progress: increase resistance; regress: use lighter tension.
Face Pull (for Rear Delts/Scapular).training_context: Excellent for improving posture and rear delt strength.

Forearm Plank (Standard Plank) [oai_cita.fascia: Engages core fascia to support spinal alignment.
Forearm Plank (Standard Plank) [oai_cita.instructions: Hold a plank position with elbows beneath shoulders and a straight line from head to heels.
Forearm Plank (Standard Plank) [oai_cita.progressions_regressions: Progress: increase hold time or add dynamic variations; regress: perform on knees.
Forearm Plank (Standard Plank) [oai_cita.safety_contraindications: Avoid if experiencing lower back or neck pain.
Forearm Plank (Standard Plank) [oai_cita.coach_tips: Keep your core tight and avoid sagging hips.
Forearm Plank (Standard Plank) [oai_cita.training_context: A fundamental exercise for building core stability and endurance.

Straight-Arm Plank (High Plank).instructions: Assume a push-up position with arms fully extended; hold your body in a straight line.
Straight-Arm Plank (High Plank).progressions_regressions: Progress: increase hold duration; regress: perform on knees.
Straight-Arm Plank (High Plank).safety_contraindications: Ensure proper form to avoid lower back sag.

Side Plank [oai_citation_attribution:49‡.instructions: Lie on your side, support your body on one forearm, and lift your hips to form a straight line.

Side Plank [oai_citation_attribution:49‡.training_context: Excellent for core and oblique stabilization.

Reverse Plank.training_context: Used to strengthen the posterior chain and core stability.

Single-Leg Plank.training_context: Enhances unilateral core stability and balance.

Single-Arm Plank.progressions_regressions: Progress: extend hold time; regress: perform with both arms.
Single-Arm Plank.safety_contraindications: Not recommended for beginners due to high demand.

Side Plank with Leg Lift.coach_tips: Focus on a controlled lift and maintaining alignment.

Incline Plank.training_context: Eases the difficulty of a standard plank for beginners.

Crunch.instructions: Lie on your back and curl your upper body toward your knees.
Crunch.progressions_regressions: Progress: add resistance; regress: perform partial crunches.

Crunch.training_context: A basic exercise for abdominal endurance and strength.

Reverse Crunch.safety_contraindications: Avoid if lower back pain is present.
Reverse Crunch.coach_tips: Focus on contracting your lower abs.

Box Jump [oai_citation_attribution:56‡he.training_context: Common in plyometric training for power development.

Burpee.fascia: Engages full-body fascia in coordinated movement.
Burpee.tendons: Moderate load on multiple tendon groups.
Burpee.instructions: From a standing position, drop into a squat, kick your feet back into a plank, perform a push-up, return to squat, and jump up.
Burpee.progressions_regressions: Progress: add a push-up; regress: remove the jump.
Burpee.safety_contraindications: Avoid if joint pain or poor conditioning is present.

Clapping Push-Up.safety_contraindications: Avoid if joint pain is present.
